member.name: T:SFML.Audio.Listener
member.summary: The audio listener is the point in the scene from where all the sounds are heard

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Listener.GlobalVolume
member.summary: The volume is a number between 0 and 100; it is combined with the individual volume of each sound / music. The default value for the volume is 100 (maximum).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Listener.Position
member.summary: 3D position of the listener (default is (0, 0, 0))

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Listener.Direction
member.summary: The direction (also called "at vector") is the vector pointing forward from the listener's perspective. Together with the up vector, it defines the 3D orientation of the listener in the scene. The direction vector doesn't have to be normalized. The default listener's direction is (0, 0, -1).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Listener.UpVector
member.summary: The up vector is the vector that points upward from the listener's perspective. Together with the direction, it defines the 3D orientation of the listener in the scene. The up vector doesn't have to be normalized. The default listener's up vector is (0, 1, 0). It is usually not necessary to change it, especially in 2D scenarios.

member.name: T:SFML.Audio.Music
member.summary: Streamed music played from an audio file

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.Music.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a music from an audio file
member.param: Path of the music file to open

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.Music.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Constructs a music from a custom stream

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.Music.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Constructs a music from an audio file in memory
member.param: Byte array containing the file contents

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.Music.Play
member.summary:
Start or resume playing the audio stream.
This function starts the stream if it was stopped, resumes it if it was paused, and restarts it from beginning if it was it already playing. This function uses its own thread so that it doesn't block the rest of the program while the stream is played.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.Music.Pause
member.summary:
Pause the audio stream.
This function pauses the stream if it was playing, otherwise (stream already paused or stopped) it has no effect.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.Music.Stop
member.summary:
Stop playing the audio stream.
This function stops the stream if it was playing or paused, and does nothing if it was already stopped. It also resets the playing position (unlike Pause()).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.SampleRate
member.summary:
Sample rate of the music.
The sample rate is the number of audio samples played per second. The higher, the better the quality.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.ChannelCount
member.summary: Number of channels (1 = mono, 2 = stereo)

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Status
member.summary: Current status of the music (see SoundStatus enum)

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Duration
member.summary: Total duration of the music

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Loop
member.summary:
Flag if the music should loop after reaching the end.
If set, the music will restart from beginning after reaching the end and so on, until it is stopped or Loop = false is set. The default looping state for music is false.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Pitch
member.summary:
Pitch of the music.
The pitch represents the perceived fundamental frequency of a sound; thus you can make a sound more acute or grave by changing its pitch. A side effect of changing the pitch is to modify the playing speed of the sound as well. The default value for the pitch is 1.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Volume
member.summary:
Volume of the music.
The volume is a value between 0 (mute) and 100 (full volume). The default value for the volume is 100.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Position
member.summary:
3D position of the music in the audio scene.
Only sounds with one channel (mono sounds) can be spatialized. The default position of a sound is (0, 0, 0).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.RelativeToListener
member.summary:
Make the music's position relative to the listener or absolute.
Making a sound relative to the listener will ensure that it will always be played the same way regardless the position of the listener. This can be useful for non-spatialized sounds, sounds that are produced by the listener, or sounds attached to it. The default value is false (position is absolute).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.MinDistance
member.summary:
Minimum distance of the music.
The "minimum distance" of a sound is the maximum distance at which it is heard at its maximum volume. Further than the minimum distance, it will start to fade out according to its attenuation factor. A value of 0 ("inside the head of the listener") is an invalid value and is forbidden. The default value of the minimum distance is 1.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.Attenuation
member.summary:
Attenuation factor of the music.
The attenuation is a multiplicative factor which makes the music more or less loud according to its distance from the listener. An attenuation of 0 will produce a non-attenuated sound, i.e. its volume will always be the same whether it is heard from near or from far. On the other hand, an attenuation value such as 100 will make the sound fade out very quickly as it gets further from the listener. The default value of the attenuation is 1.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.PlayingOffset
member.summary:
Current playing position of the music.
The playing position can be changed when the music is either paused or playing.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.Music.LoopPoints
member.summary:
Current loop points of the music.
Since setting performs some adjustments on the provided values and rounds them to internal samples, getting this value later is not guaranteed to return the same times passed into it. However, it is guaranteed to return times that will map to the valid internal samples of this Music if they are later set again.

member.summary: Base class intended for capturing sound data

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.Start
member.summary:
Start the capture using the default sample rate (44100 Hz).
Please note that only one capture can happen at the same time.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.Start(System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Start the capture.
The sampleRate parameter defines the number of audio samples captured per second. The higher, the better the quality (for example, 44100 samples/sec is CD quality). This function uses its own thread so that it doesn't block the rest of the program while the capture runs.
Please note that only one capture can happen at the same time.
member.param: Sound frequency; the more samples, the higher the quality (44100 by default = CD quality)

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.Stop
member.summary: Stop the capture

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.SampleRate
member.summary: Sample rate of the sound recorder.
member.remarks: The sample rate defines the number of audio samples captured per second. The higher, the better the quality (for example, 44100 samples/sec is CD quality).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.ChannelCount
member.summary: Get/Set the channel count of the audio capture device
member.remarks: This method allows you to specify the number of channels used for recording. Currently only 16-bit mono (1) and 16-bit stereo (2) are supported.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.IsAvailable
member.summary: Check if the system supports audio capture.
member.remarks: This function should always be called before using the audio capture features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use the SoundRecorder or one of its derived classes will fail.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.ToString
member.summary: Provide a string describing the object

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.OnStart
member.summary:
Start capturing audio data.
This virtual function may be overridden by a derived class if something has to be done every time a new capture starts. If not, this function can be ignored; the default implementation does nothing.
member.returns: False to abort recording audio data, true to continue

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.OnProcessSamples(System.Int16[])
member.summary:
Process a new chunk of recorded samples.
This virtual function is called every time a new chunk of recorded data is available. The derived class can then do whatever it wants with it (storing it, playing it, sending it over the network, etc.).
member.returns: False to stop recording audio data, true to continue

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.OnStop
member.summary:
Stop capturing audio data.
This virtual function may be overridden by a derived class if something has to be done every time the capture ends. If not, this function can be ignored; the default implementation does nothing.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.SetProcessingInterval(SFML.System.Time)
member.summary:
The processing interval controls the period between calls to the onProcessSamples function. You may want to use a small interval if you want to process the recorded data in real time, for example.
Note: this is only a hint, the actual period may vary. So don't rely on this parameter to implement precise timing.
The default processing interval is 100 ms.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.AvailableDevices
member.summary: Get the list of the names of all available audio capture devices

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.DefaultDevice
member.summary: Get the name of the default audio capture device

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.SetDevice(System.String)
member.summary: Set the audio capture device
member.param: The name of the audio capture device
member.returns: True, if it was able to set the requested device

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundRecorder.GetDevice
member.summary: Get the name of the current audio capture device
member.returns: The name of the current audio capture device

member.summary: Handle the destruction of the object
member.param: Is the GC disposing the object, or is it an explicit call ?

member.summary: Function called directly by the C library ; convert arguments and forward them to the internal virtual function
member.param: Pointer to the array of samples
Number of samples in the array
member.returns: False to stop recording audio data, true to continue

member.name: T:SFML.Audio.SoundStream
member.summary: Abstract base class for streamed audio sources

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Play
member.summary:
Start or resume playing the audio stream.
This function starts the stream if it was stopped, resumes it if it was paused, and restarts it from beginning if it was it already playing. This function uses its own thread so that it doesn't block the rest of the program while the stream is played.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Pause
member.summary:
Pause the audio stream.
This function pauses the stream if it was playing, otherwise (stream already paused or stopped) it has no effect.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Stop
member.summary:
Stop playing the audio stream.
This function stops the stream if it was playing or paused, and does nothing if it was already stopped. It also resets the playing position (unlike pause()).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.SampleRate
member.summary:
Sample rate of the stream
The sample rate is the number of audio samples played per second. The higher, the better the quality.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.ChannelCount
member.summary: Number of channels (1 = mono, 2 = stereo)

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Status
member.summary: Current status of the sound stream (see SoundStatus enum)

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Loop
member.summary:
Flag if the music should loop after reaching the end.
If set, the music will restart from beginning after reaching the end and so on, until it is stopped or Loop = false is set. The default looping state for music is false.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Pitch
member.summary:
Pitch of the stream.
The pitch represents the perceived fundamental frequency of a sound; thus you can make a sound more acute or grave by changing its pitch. A side effect of changing the pitch is to modify the playing speed of the sound as well. The default value for the pitch is 1.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Volume
member.summary:
Volume of the stream.
The volume is a value between 0 (mute) and 100 (full volume). The default value for the volume is 100.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Position
member.summary:
3D position of the stream in the audio scene.
Only sounds with one channel (mono sounds) can be spatialized. The default position of a sound is (0, 0, 0).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.RelativeToListener
member.summary:
Make the stream's position relative to the listener or absolute.
Making a sound relative to the listener will ensure that it will always be played the same way regardless the position of the listener. This can be useful for non-spatialized sounds, sounds that are produced by the listener, or sounds attached to it. The default value is false (position is absolute).

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.MinDistance
member.summary:
Minimum distance of the music.
The "minimum distance" of a sound is the maximum distance at which it is heard at its maximum volume. Further than the minimum distance, it will start to fade out according to its attenuation factor. A value of 0 ("inside the head of the listener") is an invalid value and is forbidden. The default value of the minimum distance is 1.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Attenuation
member.summary:
Attenuation factor of the stream.
The attenuation is a multiplicative factor which makes the music more or less loud according to its distance from the listener. An attenuation of 0 will produce a non-attenuated sound, i.e. its volume will always be the same whether it is heard from near or from far. On the other hand, an attenuation value such as 100 will make the sound fade out very quickly as it gets further from the listener. The default value of the attenuation is 1.

member.name: P:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.PlayingOffset
member.summary:
Current playing position of the stream.
The playing position can be changed when the music is either paused or playing.

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.ToString
member.summary: Provide a string describing the object

member.name: M:SFML.Audio.SoundStream.Initialize(System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Set the audio stream parameters, you must call it before Play()
member.param: Sample rate, in samples per second

member.name: T:SFML.Graphics.PrimitiveType
member.summary:
Types of primitives that a VertexArray can render.
Points and lines have no area, therefore their thickness will always be 1 pixel, regardless the current transform and view.

members.member: List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle
List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTarget.MapPixelToCoords(SFML.System.Vector2i)
member.summary:
Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates, using the current view
This function is an overload of the MapPixelToCoords function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapPixelToCoords(point, target.GetView());

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTarget.MapPixelToCoords(SFML.System.Vector2i,SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary:
Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates
This function finds the 2D position that matches the given pixel of the render-target. In other words, it does the inverse of what the graphics card does, to find the initial position of a rendered pixel.
Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (10, 50) in your render-target may map to the point (150, 75) in your 2D world -- if the view is translated by (140, 25).
For render-windows, this function is typically used to find which point (or object) is located below the mouse cursor.
This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTarget.MapCoordsToPixel(SFML.System.Vector2f)
member.summary:
Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates, using the current view
This function is an overload of the mapCoordsToPixel function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapCoordsToPixel(point, target.GetView());
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTarget.MapCoordsToPixel(SFML.System.Vector2f,SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary:
Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates
This function finds the pixel of the render-target that matches the given 2D point. In other words, it goes through the same process as the graphics card, to compute the final position of a rendered point.
Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25).
This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTarget.PushGLStates
member.summary:
Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices.
This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that: \li SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code \li your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function
More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions. Example:
// OpenGL code here... window.PushGLStates(); window.Draw(...); window.Draw(...); window.PopGLStates(); // OpenGL code here...
Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the ResetGLStates function if you do so.

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTarget.PopGLStates
member.summary:
Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices.
See the description of PushGLStates to get a detailed description of these functions.

Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25).
This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.GenerateMipmap
member.summary: Generate a mipmap using the current texture data
member.remarks: This function is similar to and operates on the texture used as the target for drawing. Be aware that any draw operation may modify the base level image data. For this reason, calling this function only makes sense after all drawing is completed and display has been called. Not calling display after subsequent drawing will lead to undefined behavior if a mipmap had been previously generated.
member.returns: True if mipmap generation was successful, false if unsuccessful

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.PushGLStates
member.summary:
Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices.
This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that: \li SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code \li your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function
More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions. Example:
// OpenGL code here... window.PushGLStates(); window.Draw(...); window.Draw(...); window.PopGLStates(); // OpenGL code here...
Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the ResetGLStates function if you do so.

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.PopGLStates
member.summary:
Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices.
See the description of PushGLStates to get a detailed description of these functions.

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapPixelToCoords(SFML.System.Vector2i)
member.summary:
Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates, using the current view
This function is an overload of the MapPixelToCoords function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapPixelToCoords(point, target.GetView());

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapPixelToCoords(SFML.System.Vector2i,SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary:
Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates
This function finds the 2D position that matches the given pixel of the render-target. In other words, it does the inverse of what the graphics card does, to find the initial position of a rendered pixel.
Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (10, 50) in your render-target may map to the point (150, 75) in your 2D world -- if the view is translated by (140, 25).
For render-windows, this function is typically used to find which point (or object) is located below the mouse cursor.
This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapCoordsToPixel(SFML.System.Vector2f)

Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates, using the current view
This function is an overload of the mapCoordsToPixel function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapCoordsToPixel(point, target.GetView());

This function finds the pixel of the render-target that matches the given 2D point. In other words, it goes through the same process as the graphics card, to compute the final position of a rendered point.
Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25).
This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.Shader.SetUniform(System.String,SFML.Graphics.Texture)
member.summary: Specify a texture as sampler2D uniform

remarks.para: name is the name of the variable to change in the shader. The corresponding parameter in the shader must be a 2D texture (sampler2D GLSL type).

Example:
uniform sampler2D the_texture; // this is the variable in the shader
sf::Texture texture; ... shader.setUniform("the_texture", texture);
It is important to note that must remain alive as long as the shader uses it, no copy is made internally.

To use the texture of the object being drawn, which cannot be known in advance, you can pass the special value Shader.CurrentTexture:
shader.setUniform("the_texture", Shader.CurrentTexture);

member.param: Name of the texture in the shader

member.summary: Specify current texture as \p sampler2D uniform

remarks.para: This overload maps a shader texture variable to the texture of the object being drawn, which cannot be known in advance. The second argument must be . The corresponding parameter in the shader must be a 2D texture (sampler2D GLSL type).

member.param: Name of the texture in the shader

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.Texture.GenerateMipmap
member.summary: Generate a mipmap using the current texture data

remarks.para: Mipmaps are pre-computed chains of optimized textures. Each level of texture in a mipmap is generated by halving each of the previous level's dimensions. This is done until the final level has the size of 1x1. The textures generated in this process may make use of more advanced filters which might improve the visual quality of textures when they are applied to objects much smaller than they are. This is known as minification. Because fewer texels (texture elements) have to be sampled from when heavily minified, usage of mipmaps can also improve rendering performance in certain scenarios.

Mipmap generation relies on the necessary OpenGL extension being available. If it is unavailable or generation fails due to another reason, this function will return false. Mipmap data is only valid from the time it is generated until the next time the base level image is modified, at which point this function will have to be called again to regenerate it.

member.returns: True if mipmap generation was successful, false if unsuccessful

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.Texture.Swap(SFML.Graphics.Texture)

member.name: P:SFML.Graphics.Texture.Srgb
member.summary: Enable or disable conversion from sRGB

remarks.para: When providing texture data from an image file or memory, it can either be stored in a linear color space or an sRGB color space. Most digital images account for gamma correction already, so they would need to be "uncorrected" back to linear color space before being processed by the hardware. The hardware can automatically convert it from the sRGB color space to a linear color space when it gets sampled. When the rendered image gets output to the final framebuffer, it gets converted back to sRGB.
After enabling or disabling sRGB conversion, make sure to reload the texture data in order for the setting to take effect.
This option is only useful in conjunction with an sRGB capable framebuffer. This can be requested during window creation.

member.name: T:SFML.Graphics.Transformable
member.summary: Decomposed transform defined by a position, a rotation and a scale
member.remarks: A note on coordinates and undistorted rendering: By default, SFML (or more exactly, OpenGL) may interpolate drawable objects such as sprites or texts when rendering. While this allows transitions like slow movements or rotations to appear smoothly, it can lead to unwanted results in some cases, for example blurred or distorted objects. In order to render a SFML.Graphics.Drawable object pixel-perfectly, make sure the involved coordinates allow a 1:1 mapping of pixels in the window to texels (pixels in the texture). More specifically, this means: * The object's position, origin and scale have no fractional part * The object's and the view's rotation are a multiple of 90 degrees * The view's center and size have no fractional part

member.name: T:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.UsageSpecifier
member.summary:
Usage specifiers
If data is going to be updated once or more every frame, set the usage to Stream. If data is going to be set once and used for a long time without being modified, set the usage to Static. For everything else Dynamic should be a good compromise.

member.name: P:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Available
member.summary:
Whether or not the system supports vertex buffers
This function should always be called before using the vertex buffer features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use sf::VertexBuffer will fail.

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.#ctor(System.UInt32,SFML.Graphics.PrimitiveType,SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.UsageSpecifier)
member.summary:
Create a new vertex buffer with a specific PrimitiveType and usage specifier.
Creates the vertex buffer, allocating enough graphcis memory to hold \p vertexCount vertices, and sets its primitive type to \p type and usage to \p usage.

member.summary: Total vertex count

OpenGL handle of the vertex buffer or 0 if not yet created
You shouldn't need to use this property, unless you have very specific stuff to implement that SFML doesn't support, or implement a temporary workaround until a bug is fixed.

member.name: P:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.PrimitiveType
member.summary: The type of primitives drawn by the vertex buffer

member.summary: The usage specifier for the vertex buffer

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(SFML.Graphics.Vertex[],System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices offset is specified as the number of vertices to skip from the beginning of the buffer.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated.
If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails.
No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer
Offset in the buffer to copy to

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(SFML.Graphics.Vertex[])
member.summary:
Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices assuming an offset of 0 and a vertex count the length of the passed array.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated.
If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails.
No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer

member.name: M:SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(SFML.Graphics.Vertex[],System.UInt32)
member.summary:
Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices assuming a vertex count the length of the passed array.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data.
If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated.
If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails.
No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer
Offset in the buffer to copy to

Create a native system cursor

member.name: M:SFML.Window.Cursor.#ctor(System.Byte[],SFML.System.Vector2u,SFML.System.Vector2u)
member.summary:
Create a cursor with the provided image
Pixels must be an array of width by height pixels in 32-bit RGBA format. If not, this will cause undefined behavior.
If pixels is null or either width or height are 0, the current cursor is left unchanged and the function will return false.
In addition to specifying the pixel data, you can also specify the location of the hotspot of the cursor. The hotspot is the pixel coordinate within the cursor image which will be located exactly where the mouse pointer position is. Any mouse actions that are performed will return the window/screen location of the hotspot.
Warning: On Unix, the pixels are mapped into a monochrome bitmap: pixels with an alpha channel to 0 are transparent, black if the RGB channel are close to zero, and white otherwise.
member.param: Array of pixels of the image
Width and height of the image

member.name: M:SFML.Window.Joystick.IsConnected(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Check if a joystick is connected
member.param: Index of the joystick to check
member.returns: True if the joystick is connected, false otherwise

members.member:
Return the number of buttons supported by a joystick
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns 0. Index of the joystick Number of buttons supported by the joystick

Check if a joystick supports a given axis
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns false. Index of the joystick Axis to check True if the joystick supports the axis, false otherwise

Check if a joystick button is pressed
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns false. Index of the joystick Button to check True if the button is pressed, false otherwise

Get the current position of a joystick axis
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns 0. Index of the joystick Axis to check Current position of the axis, in range [-100 .. 100]

Update the states of all joysticks
This function is used internally by SFML, so you normally don't have to call it explicitly. However, you may need to call it if you have no window yet (or no window at all): in this case the joysticks states are not updated automatically.

members.member:
Get the current position of the mouse
This function returns the current position of the mouse cursor in desktop coordinates. Current position of the mouse

Get the current position of the mouse
This function returns the current position of the mouse cursor relative to a window. Reference window Current position of the mouse

Set the current position of the mouse
This function sets the current position of the mouse cursor in desktop coordinates. New position of the mouse

Set the current position of the mouse
This function sets the current position of the mouse cursor relative to a window. New position of the mouse Reference window

member.name: M:SFML.Window.Window.SetMouseCursorGrabbed(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Grab or release the mouse cursor
member.param: True to grab, false to release
member.remarks: If set, grabs the mouse cursor inside this window's client area so it may no longer be moved outside its bounds. Note that grabbing is only active while the window has focus and calling this function for fullscreen windows won't have any effect (fullscreen windows always grab the cursor).
